Why do lots rappers who started in the 90s and 2000s had very deep hardcore rough accents for their age. Like Juvenile on his first album, he sounded 30 years old and he was only like 23/24 years old. Then you have rappers like Kendrick Lamar, J-Cole, YG etc who have like slightly slurred mumble pop style pitch flows and it sounds like a teenager rapping. Like it ainâ€™t as hardcore/rough in your face deep accent. Like is it something to do with the style of how hip hop is made now or the way itâ€™s mixed and mastered now or do rappers donâ€™t wanna do those style of flows anymore? Idk Iâ€™m just generally curious because I just noticed it when I listen to a lot of understand or mainstream stuff from the old days, like rappers sounded and looked older then their age and had more raw aggressive or deep voices.

I've watched tiny desk for years and every since Tank and the Bangas, there has been an effort to highlight Black musicians. What's sad is that while tiny desk usually highlights artists that are underground or not well known, the Black artists featured are typically quite huge to the culture. It is so cool that society as a whole is learning more and  also becoming more familiar with where samples today are coming from. I've been introduced to new artists (new to me), Black and others, and that's what I've always loved about tiny desk. Lastly, when a Black person plays tiny desk to clean up on Saturday morning, you know it's a BIG DEAL!!!  Please keep this inclusive staff employed and well paid!! Now, let's start bringing in international artists!! Blitz the Ambassador next!!!

Black Joy can mean many things but most importantly it means celebrating when you could, and perhaps should, be angry or mournful.  It is the act of producing art out of pain and it in this way it is an "essential act of survival." Black Joy is also the "idea that Black people can be happy, despite their trauma and history of oppression." Is there a better example than this Tiny Desk?  Juvenile and Manny Fresh turned Tiny Desk into the metaphorical black and tan Juke Joint. Black and tan clubs were juke joints which catered to a multiracial clientele. Jukes are/were the celebratory space mapping the cultural sounds of the Mississippi Delta. In the last shot of Manny Fresh in the crowd it is hard not to smile at the joy that is emanating from the crowd. The joy is infectious and is probably why most of the comments below are some expression of gratitude for allowing us to share in that joy.
I love my city so gotdayum much!! Thank youNPR!! You did good

From Juvenile's energy and vocal control, to Mannie's energy and improv( ex: vocoder on 400 Degreez & playing instrument from "Go D.J" on "Ha"), to the Band's awesome play & balance between smooth/hype sounds ("Slow Motion", "I Need a Hot Girl"); this was A1 musicianship!  The Amours rendition of "Rodeo" was smooth and Jon Baptiste and Trombone Shorty added their flavor as well. The Louisiana Philharmonic had that the clean sound and Mannie and Juve brought it home. The crowd did their thing too. Shoutout to Tiny Desk.
